page.title: 01SYDENHAM DAMEREL/LAMERTON
page.content: The area is rural, with good soil. The land is convoluted into 'combes', and is wooded with both deciduous and coniferous copses. Population is sparse, the majority based in agricultural pursuits, with some commuting to the nearby towns. Public services are minimal. The water table flows southwest towards the River Tamar, and there are many natural springs.There are several disused mines which are monuments to a brief period of wealth. Most of the dwellings are built from locally quarried stone. The quarries are now defunct. People are for the main, locals, and are friendly though reticent with strangers, and treat surveys such as this with suspicion.
